entry.title: Python Unicode CSV Reader/Writer
entry.summary:
So there are times that Python's implementation of Unicode can be quite frustrating. I can't count how many times I have been working with CSV files, pulling data out of another file format or extracting data from a database, only to get an ASCII cannot decode error. I found the handy code below that does a pretty fair job of handling reading and writing Unicode CSV files. I pulled this straight from the Python documenation CSV, so I take no credit (or blame) for it. 

import csv, codecs, cStringIO

class UTF8Recoder:
    """
    Iterator that reads an encoded stream and reencodes the input to UTF-8
    """
    def __init__(self, f, encoding):
        self.reader = codecs.getreader(encoding)(f)

    def __iter__(self):
        return self

    def next(self):
        return self.reader.next().encode("utf-8")

class UnicodeReader:
    """
    A CSV reader which will iterate over lines in the CSV file "f",
    which is encoded in the given encoding.
    """

    def __init__(self, f, dialect=csv.excel, encoding="utf-8", **kwds):
        f = UTF8Recoder(f, encoding)
        self.reader = csv.reader(f, dialect=dialect, **kwds)

    def next(self):
        row = self.reader.next()
        return [unicode(s, "utf-8") for s in row]

    def __iter__(self):
        return self

class UnicodeWriter:
    """
    A CSV writer which will write rows to CSV file "f",
    which is encoded in the given encoding.
    """

    def __init__(self, f, dialect=csv.excel, encoding="utf-8", **kwds):
        # Redirect output to a queue
        self.queue = cStringIO.StringIO()
        self.writer = csv.writer(self.queue, dialect=dialect, **kwds)
        self.stream = f
        self.encoder = codecs.getincrementalencoder(encoding)()

    def writerow(self, row):
        self.writer.writerow([unicode(s).encode("utf-8") for s in row])
        # Fetch UTF-8 output from the queue ...
        data = self.queue.getvalue()
        data = data.decode("utf-8")
        # ... and reencode it into the target encoding
        data = self.encoder.encode(data)
        # write to the target stream
        self.stream.write(data)
        # empty queue
        self.queue.truncate(0)

    def writerows(self, rows):
        for row in rows:
            self.writerow(row)

entry.title: ArcGIS Raster Footprints
entry.summary:
Occasionally while working with rasters in ArcGIS I have the need to create "footprints" of the extent of each raster. For a while we just used the minimum bounding rectangle of each raster, but then our clients requested to see the actual boundary. There are several raster toolsets that will accomplish this, but typically require a higher level of ArcGIS use or were slow because they actually processed the image to determine the extent of coverage. We were typically georeferencing historical maps so we would crop the images to the extent we required. The solution we ended up with utilizes the world file that is created when the georeferencing takes place. Based on the extents and rotation of the coordinates in the world file we create a polygon. Below is the Python code we came up.

import arcpy
import os
from xml.dom.minidom import parse

def get_raster_bounding_poly(raster, worldfile):
    """
    Create footprint polygon based on pixel size and rotation of raster image.
    Use worldfile to determine scale and rotation. Pass in raster image and
    path to world file to return arcpy.Polygon of footprint of the raster image.
    """
    wf_values = read_world(worldfile)
    px_rows = int(arcpy.GetRasterProperties_management(raster, "ROWCOUNT").getOutput(0))
    px_columns = int(arcpy.GetRasterProperties_management(raster, "COLUMNCOUNT").getOutput(0))
    thePoints = arcpy.Array()
    (x, y) = get_coords_from_raster(0, 0, wf_values)
    topLeft = arcpy.Point(x, y)
    (x, y) = get_coords_from_raster(px_columns, 0, wf_values)
    topRight = arcpy.Point(x, y)
    (x, y) = get_coords_from_raster(px_columns, px_rows, wf_values)
    botRight = arcpy.Point(x, y)
    (x, y) = get_coords_from_raster(0, px_rows, wf_values)
    botLeft = arcpy.Point(x, y)
    thePoints.add(topLeft)
    thePoints.add(topRight)
    thePoints.add(botRight)
    thePoints.add(botLeft)
    thePoints.add(topLeft)
    return arcpy.Polygon(thePoints)

def get_raster_list(thePath):
    "Helper function to set env.workspace and return list of Rasters"
    arcpy.env.workspace = thePath
    return arcpy.ListRasters()

def read_world(worldfile):
    "Read WorldFile from disk and put variables into Dict()"
    with open(worldfile, "r") as wf:
        theVals = [float(x.strip()) for x in wf.readlines()]
    myVals = dict(A=theVals[0],
                  D=theVals[1],
                  B=theVals[2],
                  E=theVals[3],
                  C=theVals[4],
                  F=theVals[5])
    return myVals

def get_coords_from_raster(x, y, worldVals):
    "Pass x,y as pixel positions from image along with Dict of world file values to return back map coords"
    x1 = (worldVals.get('A') * x) + (worldVals.get('B') * y) + worldVals.get('C')
    y1 = (worldVals.get('D') * x) + (worldVals.get('E') * y) + worldVals.get('F')
    return (x1, y1)

def determine_wf_name(rasterPath, raster):
    "Determine the world file name based on raster (tif, jpg, bil)"
    wfname = None
    (fn, ext) = os.path.splitext(raster)
    if ext.lower().startswith(".tif"):
        if os.path.exists(os.path.join(rasterPath, fn + ".tfw")):
            wfname =  fn + ".tfw"
        elif os.path.exists(os.path.join(rasterPath, fn + ".tifw")):
            wfname =  fn + ".tifw"
        elif os.path.exists(os.path.join(rasterPath, fn + ".tfwx")):
            wfname =  fn + ".tfwx"
    elif ext.lower().startswith(".jpg"):
        if os.path.exists(os.path.join(rasterPath, fn + ".jgw")):
            wfname =  fn + ".jgw"
        elif os.path.exists(os.path.join(rasterPath, fn + ".jpgw")):
            wfname =  fn + ".jpgw"
        elif os.path.exists(os.path.join(rasterPath, fn + ".jgwx")):
            wfname =  fn + ".jgwx"
    elif ext.lower().startswith(".bil"):
        if os.path.exists(os.path.join(rasterPath, fn + ".blw")):
            wfname =  fn + ".blw"
        elif os.path.exists(os.path.join(rasterPath, fn + ".bilw")):
            wfname =  fn + ".bilw"
        elif os.path.exists(os.path.join(rasterPath, fn + ".bilx")):
            wfname =  fn + ".bilx"
    if wfname:
        return os.path.join(rasterPath, wfname)
    else:
        return None

def get_raster_spatial_reference(theXml):
    "Return the SpatialReference base on WKT from aux.xml file for Georeferenced Rasters"
    myXml = parse(theXml)

    wkt_elements = myXml.getElementsByTagName("WKT")
    if len(wkt_elements) > 0:
        wkt = wkt_elements[0]
    else:
        print "No WKT text"
        return None

    wktText = wkt.firstChild.data
    sr = arcpy.SpatialReference()
    sr.loadFromString(wktText)
    return sr

entry.title: Pelican Article Creator
entry.summary:
I found myself having to look up old articles or refer back to the Pelican documentation in order to remember what metadata to include at the top of each article. I placed the python script below in the root directory of my blog (right next to the pelicanconf.py). It will generate the stub of an article, that I can then open up and write the content for.

import os
import datetime
import re

CONTENT = os.path.join(os.path.dirname(os.path.realpath(__file__)), 'content')

def slugify(text):
    result = unicode(re.sub("\W+", "-", text.replace("'","").strip()).lower())
    if result.endswith(u"-"):
        result = result[:-1]
    return result

def gather_user_data():
    myData = {}
    myData['title'] = raw_input("Title: ")
    myData['category'] = raw_input("Category: ")
    myData['tags'] = raw_input("Tags (comma separated): ")
    myData['summary'] = raw_input("Summary: ")
    myData['slug'] = slugify(myData['title'])
    return myData

def write_content(data):
    outFileName = os.path.join(CONTENT, data['slug'] + '.md')
    if os.path.exists(outFileName):
        print "File already exists!"
        return False
    with open(outFileName, "w") as outFile:
        txtTitle = "Title: {0}\n".format(data['title'])
        outFile.write(txtTitle)
        txtDate = "Date: {0}\n".format(datetime.datetime.now().\
            strftime("%Y-%m-%d %H:%M"))
        outFile.write(txtDate)
        category = "Category: {0}\n".format(data['category'])
        outFile.write(category)
        txtTag = "Tags: {0}\n".format(data['tags'])
        outFile.write(txtTag)
        txtSlug = "Slug: {0}\n".format(data['slug'])
        outFile.write(txtSlug)
        txtAuthor = "Author: {0}\n".format("JMG")
        outFile.write(txtAuthor)
        txtSummary = "Summary: {0}\n".format(data['summary'])
        outFile.write(txtSummary)

def main():
    write_content(gather_user_data())

if __name__ == '__main__':
    main()

entry.title: Pelican for Static Blogging
entry.summary:
Background

I'm an opinionated technology fan with various eclectic thoughts to share, so why not add another blog to the universe. I mean who wouldn't want to hear my thoughts on everything from using Python to automate my tasks at work to what type of toilet brush you should be using.

While I'm a fan of technology, more importantly, I'm cheap and want to host this for exactly $0: enter GitHub pages and Pelican. I do a fair bit of Python programming at work and at play, so I liked the sound of a Python based static site generater tool rather than the Ruby based Jekyll. Now don't get me wrong, I don't have anything against Ruby or Jekyll, I just decided to start with Pelican since it is Python based.

Software

I'm starting with Pelican as the blogging engine. I will be writing my content with Markdown. I will be working in a virtualenv setup to generate all my content.

Installing Pelican and Markdown is dead simple.

You will need to create a virtualenv first:

virtualenv pelicanenv

This will create a pelicanenv directory that will house your Python executible and install other tools (e.g. pip) that you can use to install Pelican and Markdown.

You will need to activate your pelicanenv

. pelicanenv/bin/activate

Once you have done this you can install pelican and markdown:

pip install pelican markdown

This will use the pip installation in your pelicanenv and install the latest pelican and markdown to the site-packages directory.

I'll leave it to you to read through the Getting Started guide for the rest of it, but this will get you started.

Other tools

I am using Bitbucket to store the source of the blog and publishing to GitHub. Why you ask? Did I mention that I am cheap? Bitbucket allows me to have private Git repositories for free. GitHub allows me to host my static content for free. I believe Bitbucket will allow me to do the same (see this), but is very undocumented. I may experiment with that, but for now I'll use the better documented GitHub Pages.

I am using the excellent SourceTree for working with my Git repositories.

I am using Sublimet Text as my text editor of choice.

Future

This is obviously the very basics of my new blog, and I will continue to write posts as I go through learning Pelican. Right now I'm sticking with the default theme that ships with it, but I will be experimenting with other themes and write about my experiences.

In the future I may turn on Disqus comments. I will just wait and see how much abuse I am willing to open myself up to.
